channel.title: StockHedges
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from StockHedges, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Twilio shares pop 20% for biggest gain since Covid pandemic on growth forecast
item.description: Twilio shares had their sharpest rally since 2020 on Friday after the company issued an uplifting forecast for the coming years at an investor event.

item.title: This Financial Coach Is Ready to Fix Your Marriage Too
item.description: Ramit Sethi gets couples to open up for his shows, books, podcasts and a Netflix series

item.title: The Score: Novo Nordisk, Oracle, Netflix, and More Stocks That Defined the Week
item.description: Here are some of the major companies whose stocks moved on the week’s news.

item.title: Boeing expects $4 billion loss for fourth quarter after chaotic 2024
item.description: Boeing outlined expected results and charges across its business in preliminary fourth-quarter results.

item.title: Twilio stock surges after company issues optimistic 2027 profit forecast
item.description: Twilio wants to grow in conversational artificial intelligence while also becoming more profitable.

item.title: You Can Own Elon Musk's SpaceX. But at What Price?
item.description: An ETF that can trade all day is investing in an asset that rarely changes hands. Figuring out what it’s worth is a guessing game.

item.title: Stock Investors Like Trump 2.0
item.description: Major indexes around the globe moved higher during President Trump’s first week in office.

item.title: American Express CFO says spending picked up at year-end, thanks to millennials and Gen Z
item.description: The pickup was especially fueled by millennials and Gen Z users, who spent more on experiences such as travel and entertainment.

item.title: Burberry shares jump 13% after better-than-expected quarterly sales
item.description: Burberry on Friday reported a shallower-than-expected dip in sales in the fiscal third quarter, in the first glimpse of fresh efforts to revamp the be...

item.title: The WSJ Dollar Index Falls 0.5% to 101.80
item.description: The WSJ Dollar Index was down 0.5% to 101.80 — lower for two consecutive trading days.
